Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Microbial cycling of Iron and Sulfur in Spring Creek Reservoir, Iron Mountain Mine
Award.AbstractNarration:
In July 2018, the Carr Fire burned nearly 230,000 acres, including the area surrounding the Iron Mountain Superfund Site where mine-impacted drainage is diverted into the Spring Creek Reservoir. Microbes alter the water and sediment chemistry in the reservoir and change the quality of the water flowing downstream. This year, rain falling on the burn scar during the wet season is expected to cause rapid erosion and deposit extra sediment into the lake. This project will investigate how contaminated sediments are deposited in the lakes, and how microbes transform sediment, pore water, and reservoir water. Project personnel will examine inflowing sediments, microbial communities from the sediment, as well as water quality in the reservoir following storm events in the 2018/2019 season. Results will show how microbial activity changes sediment chemistry and water quality in the Spring Creek Reservoir and provide insights into similar burned over areas and mine-impacted soils. Mining activities in the Western USA has resulted in thousands of miles of streams impacted by acid mine discharge, and widespread contamination of soils by mine and smelter operations. Discharge of contaminated water and sediment from the Iron Mountain mine has historically impacted the upper Sacramento River, an important drinking water source and salmon spawning stream. The results of this project will help mine managers, local and regional environmental planners and reservoir managers understand the movement and fate of remobilized sediments, and to plan for the effects of wildfire on the vegetation and reclamation infrastructure that help to stabilize contaminated soils.

The Iron Mountain Superfund Site contains the remnants of several abandoned mines, and Spring Creek drains part of this area with the Spring Creek Debris Dam and reservoir (SCR) capturing discharge before it enters the Keswick Reservoir and Sacramento River. In July 2018, the Carr Fire burned most of the Spring Creek watershed, and thus, sedimentation is expected to be high during the 2018/19 rainy season. The influx of sediment provides an opportunity to investigate how microbial communities colonize and transform sediment and pore waters in an acid mine drainage-influenced lake. Prior research in the SCR suggests that microbial communities reduce iron and sulfate in pore waters during high reservoir levels, and that iron and sulfide oxidize when water levels are low, producing acidity and mobilizing metals. The proposed research will characterize sediment influx, how microbial communities develop within the new sediment, and how microbial activity changes pore water chemistry. The research team will sample and analyze the sediments and pore and surface water 8 times from November 2018 to 2019. Analyses will include mineralogy; iron, sulfur, oxygen, and pH of the water; and molecular analyses of the microbial communities. This research will provide fundamental insights into environmental biogeochemistry in acid mine drainage-contaminated environments and provide guidance for managing the water quality in the SCR.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research helps to quantify the impacts of post-fire sediment deposition on microbial communities, biogeochemical cycling, and water chemistry in Spring Creek Reservoir. Many lakes and reservoirs across the globe, are impacted by the accumulation of pollutants in their sediments as a result of past mining activities (e.g., Clear Lake, CA, USA; Cottage Grove Reservoir, OR, USA; Castilseras reservoir, Spain; Alcolea reservoir, Spain; Coronada reservoir, Spain; Balmer Lake, Ontario, Canada). This research provided an unprecedented opportunity to examine detailed pore water chemistry, mineralogy, and microbial communities in an impacted reservoir. Additionally, this research allowed us to track the addition of new material during large depositional events that follow wildfire. Wildfire is predicted to become more common, and the deposition of sediments following these events will likely force changes in the way that reservoirs are managed – both due to their accumulation and their influence on biogeochemical cycling. Therefore, our research may be able to help inform management decisions in the future.  

We addressed our specific objectives in the following ways:

1) Identify which Fe and S containing species were present in sediment deposited during winter storms following the Carr Fire. 

Sediment samples were sent to Dr. Kate Campbell at the USGS for mineralogical analysis. Those analyses are ongoing. Dr. Charles Alpers (USGS Sacramento) facilitated the analysis of acid volatile sulfide, total reduced sulfur, and loss on ignition in samples from the cores taken in Fall 2018. These analyses were performed at the direction of Dr. Mark Marvin-DiPasquale (USGS Menlo Park)

2) Determine how microbial communities colonized and developed in the freshly deposited sediments. 

We extracted DNA from 102 sediment samples paired with those analyzed by Dr. Campbell. Those that passed quality control were sequenced at the UC Davis Host Microbiome Systems Biology Core for 16S rRNA gene sequencing. 

3) Determine how diagenetic and microbial processes affected Fe and S cycling in the sediment and pore water.  

We analyzed 171 samples of pore water from gel probes via ICPMS at the UC Davis Interdisciplinary Center for Plasma Mass Spectrometry. Paired pore water samples were sent to Dr. Kate Campbell for the quantification of dissolved Fe. Those analyses are ongoing. 

4) Identify how the processes occurring within pore water influenced reservoir geochemistry.

Dr. Campbell modeled the mixing of pore water with surface water in Spring Creek Reservoir, followed by the oxidation and precipitation of ferric iron. These results will be combined with the results of objectives 1-3 to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the interactions between microbial communities, sediments, pore water, and the geochemistry of the surface water in Spring Creek Reservoir.   

 Significant Results: 

We found that significant sediment was deposited in the reservoir in the winter following the Carr Fire. However, the pore water profiles did not appear to change during this interval. Microbial community analyses are ongoing. Based on Dr. Campbell’s modeling, the reservoir is poised on the edge of significant pH changes, and the mixing of porewater with Spring Creek Reservoir can influence this geochemistry. 

Dr. Grettenberger and USGS collaborators Dr. Campbell and Dr. Charles Alpers attended an Iron Mountain stakeholders meeting in May 2019. At this meeting, we were able to discuss the project with other stakeholders. In October 2019, Dr. Grettenberger presented the preliminary results of this research at the Geological Society of America’s annual meeting and received valuable insight and feedback from other members of the biogeochemistry community. 

Dr. Grettenberger and members of the Sumner lab also presented a coring-based tabletop activity to elementary-aged students at the Sacramento Science Center as part of a broader effort to make integrate education and public outreach into our NSF funded research.
